article_title: Applied Materials, Tokyo Electron scrap merger plan
article_text:
An earlier version of this story misstated the timing of when doubts with the deal arose.

Bloomberg Merger’s off between Applied Materials and Tokyo Electron.

TOKYO—Applied Materials Inc. and Tokyo Electron Ltd. said that they will scrap plans to merge their operations, citing problems with the U.S. Department of Justice.

The deal, which was unveiled in September of 2013, would have created a company with an estimated market value of $29 billion. Applied AMAT, +0.72% planned to swap about $9.3 billion of its shares for Tokyo Electron 8035, -0.09%

“We viewed the merger as an opportunity to accelerate our strategy and worked hard to make it happen,” said Gary Dickerson, president and chief executive officer of Applied Materials said in a statement.

The two companies announced in 2013 that they would join in a merger of equals, in what would have been a combination of two of the semiconductor industry’s biggest suppliers.

An extended version of this story can be found at WSJ.com

More from MarketWatch

Bloomberg Merger’s off between Applied Materials and Tokyo Electron.
TOKYO—Applied Materials Inc. and Tokyo Electron Ltd. said that they will scrap plans to merge their operations, citing problems with the U.S. Department of Justice.
Applied AMAT, +0.72% planned to swap about $9.3 billion of its shares for Tokyo Electron 8035, -0.09%“We viewed the merger as an opportunity to accelerate our strategy and worked hard to make it happen,” said Gary Dickerson, president and chief executive officer of Applied Materials said in a statement.
An earlier version of this story misstated the timing of when doubts with the deal arose.
The deal, which was unveiled in September of 2013, would have created a company with an estimated market value of $29 billion.
